How to wrap a gift for someone who struggles to open presents. 🎄🎅🏼🎁

The holiday season is well & truly upon us. I don't know about you but I bought a lot of gifts in the Black Friday sales which need wrapping so I thought I'd show you this neat little hack which can help make opening gifts easier. Share it with your friends & family as a friendly hint if, like me, you're someone who struggles in this area. Ian wrapped all my gifts like this last year, it was very thoughtful & made things so much easier for me!

Unwrapping gifts can be difficult for many people from people with chronic pain to those with muscle weaknesses or those who struggle with their fine motor skills. It can be useful for young children, elderly relatives or disabled loved ones. Gift bags are great but nothing can beat the joy of ripping into a gift if it can be made more accessible. 

Here's how to wrap your gift:

1: Measure a piece of ribbon or string to the size of your gift & tie or tape a large loop at either end. 

2: Cut your paper to size & wrap your ribbon around your gift with the loops at an end opening & use the weight of the gift to keep the ribbon in place. You can tape one end of the ribbon to the gift to give more tension which will make it easier to open but only really works with boxed gifts. 

3: Wrap your gift as normal, being sure to keep the loops out at one end.

These loops means your loved ones can get a good grip without any fiddly bits meaning they can rip into their present using one or both loops, as you can see I got pretty excited. You can also keep the looped ribbon or string to reuse next year! 

Will you give this technique a try? Can you think of anything which would make opening gifts easier for someone with a disability? Let me know in the comments & remember to save this post for when you do your wrapping!

Stop judging disabled people based on ‘how disabled they look’!

If there’s one thing non-disabled people can’t seem to fathom, it’s the idea that #disabled people have fluctuating needs; as soon as we are away from a mobility aid people seem to think we’re magically cured. But with dynamic disabilities, symptoms can change week to week, day to day, even hour to hour. So this is your reminder that we are always disabled, no matter how visible our #disability is. 

Lots of people need to use #DifferentAidsForDifferentDays depending for a number of reasons. Me standing unaided for a few moments is very different to expecting me to go to the shops or walk my dog unaided. It’s just like choosing the right pair of shoes, you’d struggle running a 10k in 6 inch heels, right? You might manage for a while but you’d be pretty unhappy about it! A pair of running trainers would be much more comfortable & you could happily complete your task. Just like how I can manage a day out with just my walker but after a while I’ll get sore & tired so need my wheelchair to be able to comfortably complete my task. 

It’s perfectly normal to use different tools for different jobs. People may be able to get around their home unaided, need a stick to get to their car & then need a wheelchair to get around the shops. But this can also fluctuate; on a low pain day we might be able to manage the shops with just a stick but on a high pain day we might need our wheelchair at home. Just like an unexpected change in the weather might mean you choose different footwear.

An aid is defined as a ‘practical help’ so it’s also important to remember that if we aren’t using our ‘usual’ mobility aid for whatever reason we are actually without this help so we might actually be struggling more, as opposed to feeling better as many people often think. Aids also come in all shapes & sizes, they might be supports worn under clothing, it might be leaning on walls, furniture or loved ones or sitting down when others might stand, the things we do to support ourselves are not always obvious to those looking in. 

What do you wish people knew about having a #DynamicDisability? Let me know in the comments!

ad On International Day of People With Disabilities I’ve teamed up with @lovehoneyofficial to bust some myths around Disability, S3x & Relationships. 

Disabled people face misconceptions about their relationships & s3x lives on a daily basis but we are just as varied as non-disabled people when it comes to s3x & relationships - our needs, wants and desires, our s3xual identities, are completely individual. We aren’t aliens to be afraid of & we aren’t all the same, so just communicate, and treat us like human beings, and you could be in for a beautiful relationship or a mind-blowing night! 

Myth 1: Disabled People can’t have s3x! Many of us can, and do, have s3x in all the ways you can think of, and more. It might look a little different but you just have to think outside of the box & get creative.

Myth 2: Disabled People are burdens in relationships. Thinking non-disabled partners are heroes for ‘putting up’ with our disabilities reduces us to our disability alone & we are so much more than that! Disabled people are deserving of love & support in relationships, just like anyone else. We are not burdens to those who truly love us & interabled relationships can be very equal, we care for each other in different ways.

Myth 3: It’s okay to ask disabled people how they have s3x. There is a strange fascination & curiosity around the ways disabled people have s3x & my general rule when you want to ask a disabled person any question, be that about their medical history or their s3x life, is if you wouldn’t ask a non-disabled person, don’t ask a disabled person. It’s really none of your business.

Myth 4: Communication isn’t important. In fact it’s vital, don’t make decisions for your partner or assume anything about their abilities just because they are disabled.

Myth 5: Disabled People can’t be sexy! If there is one thing I want you to remember today it’s that Disabled People are HOT!!! 

What assumptions have you made about Disability, s3x & relationships in the past or do you currently hold? Has this video helped change some of those assumptions? Would love for you to let us know in the comments!

#Lovehoney #DisabledPersonDay #DisabledPeopleAreHot #IDPWD2022

The holidays are a busy time of year for social gatherings so I asked my followers what they wish non-disabled people knew about socialising with a disability or chronic illness & this is what they wanted you to know ahead of the festive season. 

1.The admin is intense - there is a lot of planning that goes into simply leaving the house as a disabled person: is there an accessible way to travel, will i have to book assistance or organize a carer, is the venue accessible to get into,is there somewhere I can rest if i need to - the list goes on & on - help your disabled pals out by finding out some of this info for us & booking accessible venues.

2.Many of our conditions can fluctuate by the hour so it’s really hard for us to make future plans. Remember we are just as upset, if not more upset, than you are if we have to cancel last minute or leave early but it really isn’t our fault. We want so badly to spend time with you but sometimes our health has other plans. We might not always be able to make it but please don’t stop inviting us to things.

3.Socialising is much more exhausting than you think for us. Please respect our energy & the effort we’ve made to be there because between the planning & the event itself there will be consequences for us which could mean we spend days in bed. Please don’t push us to participate in extra activities, just watching & being present can be enjoyable & is often exhausting enough.

4.Please remember that just because we look good does not necessarily mean we feel good, we often have to fake being well in order to have a good time. Pain & so many other symptoms are invisible & often we are pushing our limits to spend time with you. Don’t make assumptions based on how we look.

5.Finally winter is a nasty time for viruses so please try & avoid attending events if you are unwell or at the very least let other people attending know you are sick so they can make an informed decision because for many vulnerable people it’s just not worth the risk.

What would you add to this list? Let me know in the comments and share this to educate your loved ones.

#DisabilityEducation #DisabilityAwareness #ChronicIllnessAwareness #ChronicPain

ad The @PassengerAssistanceuk app is my number 1 hack for train travel in the UK. 

I used to be so scared of booking assistance that I'd end up avoiding it altogether & not getting the help I needed when traveling by train but the free-to-use Passenger Assistance app has been a gamechanger & I now use it for all my journeys. It’s quick & easy to book in the app or online, and in a couple of clicks, you can select which trains you're traveling on, along with the types of assistance you need hassle-free. You set up your profile then there are so many different assistance options to choose from. For this journey I was headed into London with my walker so I booked a ramp & someone to help me find a seat. The app even remembers your previous preferences so you don’t have to add your information every time you book. You can even book just 2 hours in advance, making days out around the festive period much more flexible. You get an email to confirm your assistance is booked & then you can buy your tickets as you usually would. Plus a new feature on the app means you can also rate your trip. All of this means you can get your Christmas shopping done, head to festive parties & see your friends without having to worry so much about the admin! I highly recommend downloading the Passenger Assistance app for free today.

#TapToTravel #DisabilityHacks #BabeWithAMobilityAid #DisabilityTravel #DisabledTravel #DisabilityAdvocate #DisabledInfluencer #DisabilityServices #DisabilityBlogger #ad for UK audiences only

#Accessibility Video Description: Jenni a white woman with wavy auburn hair is sat on her sofa booking passenger assistance on the app. A screen recording shows Jenni selecting her trains & clicking buttons for the assistance she needs. We see clips of her journey into London as she sits at the station with her purple walker, in her silver sparkly suit & grey coat. The ramp is placed down, she’s sat on the train wearing her mask, she rolls her walker off the train via a ramp. Jenni enjoys fun activities in London like Christmas shopping, dancing at a party, seeing friends & Christmas lights before she heads back to the station reception to get her assistance back home.

Top Tips on Managing the Holidays with a #ChronicIllness 

With social & financial pressures, the holiday season can be stressful for many but when you have a chronic illness those pressures can be intensified. So much expectation is placed on us 'because it's Christmas' & we’re often forced to do more than we usually would, meaning it can be the most flare inducing time of the year. Chronic illness doesn't know or care that it’s Christmas, pain & fatigue don't just disappear because it's the holidays. I secretly loved our little lockdown Christmases the last few years as a lot of that pressure disappeared.

🎄 Set clear boundaries & say no: Don't push yourself just because it's Christmas because the only person who will suffer is you. We can often get stuck between family & visit multiple destinations to keep the peace but if you wouldn’t do it all in one day any other time of the year don't do it for the holidays. If you really need to see everyone try & push for a more accessible option, like a zoom call.

✨ Create a rest space to get away from it all. Whether you're at home or visiting family, try& prearrange a space you can go & rest if things get too much, whether it’s a separate room with a bed or a comfy pillow in your car. If you talk about this in advance it's easier to excuse yourself on the day too.

🎅🏼 Simplify & Prioritise where you can! We can't do it all, especially at Christmas. We might want perfectly wrapped gifts & homemade food but in reality gift bags & pre prepared food are much easier meaning you can save more time & energy on the things you really love. This year I took Christmas cards off my to do list as they were just an extra thing I really didn't need to spend spoons on.

🎄 Ask for help. Again if there’s particular holiday tasks you struggle with, don't suffer in silence, ask someone else if they can help you or take on that task themselves. If you don't have the physical support, reaching out to a friend virtually for emotional support might be just as helpful.

Let me know in the comments how you are spending the holidays & what your top tip is for making it easier to manage?

I am a strong, proud, fierce disabled woman! 

There used to be someone in my life who would always make me put my mobility aids out of shot for pictures, especially my walker and especially for special days out or events. Those were the days I'd feel the most beautiful and confident but those comments could suck that joy out of me in a flash. There's a reason that person is no longer in my life.  I am proud of my aids & happy to show them off, they allow me to take part in so much of life which I would miss without them. They make me feel stronger and give me more freedom, and that's empowering and also kind of sexy! And I will never again move my aids out of shot to make someone else more comfortable, and I hope you won't either because you are a strong, proud, fierce disabled person and you deserve better. It says a lot more about them than it does about you. Aids are not something to be hidden or ashamed of!

We don't see enough disability representation in general but even less so in partywear, events & occasions marketing, we love these things too, it takes a lot of energy but getting dressed up every once in a while is one of my favourite things to do! I long to see more representation in these areas. It's something I wish I had seen when I was first diagnosed and would mean that the next generation of disabled people can feel empowered, so they never feel like they have to hide their aids and I'm extremely proud to be a tiny part of that representation!

What makes you feel strong, proud &/or fierce? Let me know in the comments!

📸: @sarahjessdarley

Everyone meet Candy the Elf! 💚❤️

Swipe to meet her friends too! I had the best day with the @ashleeentertainment team performing at Christmas parties, it's definitely helped me to get more into the festive spirit! 

Using a visible mobility aid when performing isn't something I get to do very often (I've always got a lot of supports on underneath my costumes, as I did today) but Candy being able to have her Cane (see what we did there 😜) today meant so much to me. 

Not only did it make my job that little bit easier, but it was amazing to quietly be a little bit of visible disability representation in the room and have that be met with quiet, easy acceptance. It was lovely to tell the couple of kids who asked about it the story of how Santa made my cane to give me extra support when my legs got wobbly. 

All in all a fun and magical day! Have you got any magical plans in the next few weeks? I think tomorrow's crash day will involve my sofa, popcorn and a lot of Christmas movies! Let me know what I should watch in the comments!?

Happy New Year! Here's to more adventures in 2023! ✨

It wasn't until I made this video that I realised just how much we managed to pack into this year, I also loved spotting how I use different mobility aids on different days. We've been lucky enough to have breaks away in Norfolk, the Lake District & our first holiday abroad together to Norway. It's been so amazing to finally meet so many brilliant friends from across the country in real life! From the stressful & scary start of the year where I was on an unpaid sabbatical from my day job due to my health declining & having to take the tough decision to quit that stability in favour of being fully self employed, I cannot believe the opportunities I've had & some of the work I've got to do this year. I'm very lucky to call content creation my job & I can't thank you enough for your unwavering support on that journey! I also got to fulfil a lifelong dream this year; getting a dog. We can't believe how much Coco has grown in the last 2 months, it's been hard work but we love her to bits, we are so proud of her training & she's the most amazing addition to our little family! 

If you're seeing a lot of these videos tonight do remember that they are highlights, & I didn't realise I had so many highlights this year. You don't see the stress, the sadness, the anger, the fear, the tears (there were a lot of them!) or the weeks stuck on the sofa (look what happened to march!) Those moments just aren't usually the times we have our cameras out. There have been so many hard times this year & a lot of tough decisions have been made but I'm proud of myself for getting through it, & you should be proud of yourself for getting through it too, no matter what time of year you have had.

Sending you Spoons & Love and wishing you a restful and balanced new year! I'll be back for more of your favourite hacks, disability education videos & #BabeWithAMobilityAid looks in 2023! If you have anything you'd like to see from me in 2023 let me know in the comments! 

#HappyNewYear2023 #2022YearInReview #2022Season #DisabledAndCute #DisabilityEducation #DifferentAidsForDifferentDays #DisabledJoy #DisabilityPride

ad Find your balance with @fandfclothing ✨💚

This year I am determined to find a better balance in my life, but it’s so tricky when you have a chronic illness or a disability. For example, I know that movement & being outdoors helps my body & my mind but I also know that too much movement & not enough rest & recovery can make me unwell for days & send me back to square one. Since getting our pup I’ve definitely been doing a lot more movement & we are building that movement up slowly together and F&F’s new ‘sportswear’ collection is perfect for that! 

Now I have to get dressed & leave the house most days with Coco, sportswear is my new loungewear & this range is so comfortable, versatile & affordable too, whilst still being amazing quality! It means I can walk the dog & then curl up on the sofa as soon as I get back without having to change again. I particularly love the green jogger & sweatshirt set, the colour makes me so happy which motivates me to get dressed on low days plus it’s washed beautifully despite being covered in muddy paw prints on several occasions. The navy leggings & jacket are another firm favourite with their super soft thermal layer perfect from January walks in the park.

What’s even better is that Clubcard members get great deals across sports &
athleisure with ladies leggings down to £10 and sweats/joggers only £12.50! If you’re in need of a sportswear refresh, I highly recommend popping down to your local tesco!

What’s your go to #ComfyCasual outfit? Do you have a favourite out of these 4 looks? Let me know in the comments!

Do not assume a disabled person is feeling better just because they aren't using visible aids or their usual aids. We aren't magically cured when we aren't using our walking aids, just like our eyesight doesn't magically improve when we aren't wearing our glasses. Aids & support can be invisible, just like contact lenses, or we might be struggling more if we are unable to use visible aids.

Glasses & Walking aids (canes, wheelchairs etc) can both be considered mobility aids. They both help us to get around more easily, prevent injury & give the user independence, so why do we see them so differently, especially within the younger population. Glasses are more common & something we have come to accept without question so why can’t we accept walking aids in the same way.

Never in my 10 years of wearing glasses have I had someone assume my eyesight has improved because I’m not wearing my glasses, people know eyesight doesn’t usually work like that so either assume I’m wearing contacts or that it’s difficult for me to see certain things.

I wish people would see walking aids, be that a stick, rollator or wheelchair, in the same way. I cannot tell you how many times people have said things like ‘oh, no stick today, glad you’re feeling better’ often when I'm feeling much worse without my aid and it’s super frustrating. So instead of assuming someone's pain, mobility issues or disability has magically disappeared when they don’t have their usual walking aid, start questioning your own assumptions instead.

What is an assumption you've made or had made about your disability which you would like challenged? Let me know in the comments. 

Please share this post to your stories to help raise awareness.

My Top 5 hacks for Dog Owners as a Disabled Puppy Parent

1. Double ended Rope Lead - Allows you to walk hands free perfect for people with mobility aids or hand/shoulder issues. I find the crossbody position most comfortable but you can also get waist leads online. There are also two different ways to attach the clip to the rings which is helpful & it’s super versatile so you can change the configuration to suit whoever is walking your pup. Our leads are from @cocopupuk

2. @CocoPupUK ’s dog walking bag - This bag was the 1st thing I bought before bringing Coco home. It has so many features & accessories so you can customise it to your needs, we have 2 sizes for daily walks vs days out. I love the poop bag dispenser section, treat pouch & bum bag strap. The bum bag strap option makes it amazing for mobility aid users to keep hands & arms free. It’s great to have everything you need for a walk in one place so you don’t have to think about it, just grab & go.

3. Flirt Pole - This is a life saver when you need a sit down but your pup needs to burn off some energy. They get an exciting game of chase & you barely have to move, win-win!

4. Kong - Coco has lots of chews & toys but @kongcompany are the only ones she never gets bored of because you can change it up. I love filling them with yogurt mixed with dog safe peanut butter & freezing it, keeps her busy for a good hour & is perfect whilst she’s teething!

5. Homemade Towel games - Coco has lots of puzzle games but figured them out too quickly so wrapping food up in towels for her to find is a cheap & easy alternative which keeps her busy. But use old towels because Coco has a habit of chewing through the towels to get to her treat sometimes! 

What’s your top hack for disabled dog owners? Let me know in the comments! Be sure to share this video to your stories for anyone who might find it helpful! You can follow our Puppy @CocoTheDoubleDoodle to keep up with her training.

#AmbulatoryWheelchairUsersExsist

There are lots of reasons people use wheelchairs when they are able to walk, whether it’s to reduce pain & fatigue, because they can’t walk very far or because walking would take them much longer than the average person meaning they’d struggle to get the things done. A lot of these reasons are also reasons we use cars and other forms of transport, we just don’t think about it as much because they are part of everyday life for the majority of the population. Whilst many people are physically able to walk 5 miles, for example, most people will drive that distance because it’s much quicker, it’s less tiring and it gives you more energy to enjoy the place or activity you’re headed to. Plus you would probably be pretty sore the next day if you weren’t used to that walk. Wheelchairs are not a bad thing, they are an aid, They give independence & freedom, they are something to be utilised when needed, they are simply a way of getting around just like cars, bikes, scooters and more. Let’s stop questioning and judging disabled people and take some more time to think and understand.

It’s normal and valid to use #DifferentAidsForDifferentDays just like it’s normal to use different tools for different jobs.

Just like people might wear different shoes for different activities, people may also need different mobility aids for different tasks. Or to make the same task more comfortable.

So just because you saw us with one aid yesterday it doesn’t mean we don’t need a different one today, we are simply using the right tool for the job. It’s also important to recognise that not using an aid might be the right tool for some jobs. So just like how going to the gym in heels might be uncomfortable (let’s face it painful) & potentially dangerous, going out without the right mobility aid can have the same effect for those who need them.

There are hundreds of reasons people may use different aids on different days or even different hours. It could be because a certain area in their body is flaring up & needs more support. It could be that an activity they did previously caused injury, pain or exhaustion, meaning they need more support or they may need different tools for different tasks. For example, I use my stick for short day to day activities, my walker for short trips out alone & my wheelchair for long days out or when I’m too fatigued, dizzy or in too much pain to continue walking. If I’m going to the supermarket alone it’s impractical for me to use my walker or stick when I need a trolley so I mainly rely on the trolley for support but this can make my disability more invisible.

So remember, if you see someone using an aid they wouldn’t usually use, or not using an aid when they usually would, stop, think and don’t be so quick to judge.

What aids or tools do you find most helpful for different tasks? Let me know in the comments.

When you have a chronic illness, resting is hard! 

Sure, lying on the sofa or in bed all day, binge watching a tv show sounds fun right? And it would be if it was an occasional choice instead of a regular occurrence you have no control over. It’s one thing to be able to have a lazy sunday curled up with your partner or your dog but it’s quite another to be forced into lying down because your body cannot cope with being anything but horizontal. Being forced to rest is NOT fun!

Resting is also hard because of the society we live in. Everyone expects everything immediately which puts huge pressure on people to deliver. This makes taking sick days from work or other responsibilities hard for a lot of folks, but it’s even harder for chronically ill people because we are sick everyday. Yes some days are better than others, but most people would take a day off if they were feeling our everyday level of sickness, let alone our flare level. So at what point are we, as chronically ill people, able to decide we need time off? It’s very hard to know & we can end up making ourselves more unwell in the process.

Resting is tough when you have to rest a lot, just because your body needs to rest, it doesn’t mean that your mind stops whirring, and mindfulness & meditation often just brings the pain to the forefront. Resting gets really frustrating when you just want to live ‘normally’. Resting gets boring when you’re too unwell to focus on anything enjoyable & spend your day scrolling. Rest is isolating & lonely because even though there are so many others out there who understand it can be difficult to connect when all of them are exhausted & unwell too. Resting gets depressing when all you have done is tried your best to rest for days or weeks & you don’t feel much improvement.

Rest is so important & something everyone needs to invest more time into, but it doesn’t mean it isn’t difficult when it is all you are able to do.

What do you wish others knew about the realities of resting when you have a chronic illness? Let me know in the comments & share this post to your stories.

Disabled people are strong, but we are tired.

We are tired of having to fight for our basic rights. And then being expected to be extra grateful when someone offers us the bare minimum. Tired of being overlooked, not listened to & forgotten. Tired of apologising for things which are not our fault! 

We are tired of having to prove ourselves & our needs, filling in countless forms, expending extra energy we don't have, just to do things others can do at the click of a button. It's emotionally draining as well as physically.

We're tired of having to write ourselves scripts in order to tackle the barrage of intrusive, personal questions no non-disabled person would ever be expected to answer.

We are tired of blaming ourselves for mistakes & complications which never would have happened if we had the right support in the first place. We shouldn't have to put in the extra work when it is not our disabilities but inaccessibility that's the issue. 

Please listen to disabled people, learn from the ones who have chosen to educate & hire and support disabled people & businesses so we can get a seat at the table because we are tired of fighting for our place. Disabled people are strong, and have more compassion & empathy than anyone else but we are tired of fighting alone, please fight with us.

If you aren't disabled or chronically ill I urge you to listen, share & help us in this fight. If you have a disabled friend see if there's 1 small thing you can take off their to do list this week from checking accessibility to filling out a form. 

What disability issue is something you think more people should be fighting for? Let me know in the comments & raise some awareness.

Disabled people do not owe you their story!

Just because we're #disabled , strangers think they can ask us all sorts of questions they'd never ask a non-disabled person but 'What happened to you?' is the one that comes up most often & it's so frustrating.

When I was first diagnosed I always answered, constantly reliving my medical trauma, in the hopes of raising awareness when in reality that lady on the bus in 2018 has never thought about me or my conditions again. So now I simply say, 'oh I'm just disabled' & hope people are too flummoxed to ask a follow up.

There are several reasons why it's not okay to ask a disabled person what happened to them. 

First, ask yourself why you're asking & what you'll do with that information, if it's simply curiosity it's not okay because you wouldn't ask anyone else for that level of personal info. It's like asking a stranger for their recent blood test results, a bit weird. If you need to know it's better to ask 'what are your access needs' or 'do you require xyz today?' because that's the information you need to help them & not their personal details.

Second, a lot of people are born with their disabilities so it's a little ignorant to think something must have happened to them to make them disabled. Also many disabled people are still searching for answers & don't have a diagnosis which makes questions like this tough.

Finally & most importantly it can be extremely traumatic for disabled people to be expected to relive trauma every time someone asks this. Disability can be caused after an accident or if someone is the victim of a crime or if someone has faced medical trauma or negligence. Nobody wants to have to think about that every time a curious stranger wants to know what happened so have a little compassion & think before you ask.

Remember that disabled people don't owe you a diagnosis, they don't owe you a serious answer to a rude question & they definitely don't owe you their personal & potentially traumatic medical history.

Share this to your stories to help more people realise this isn't okay & let me know how you answer this question in the comments!

In my 10 years of wearing glasses I’ve never once been asked ‘What happened to your eyes?’ and yet, in the last 6 years of using various walking aids, I've lost count of the amount of times I’ve been asked ‘What happened to your leg?’!

Firstly, no idea why it’s always assumed my leg is the problem (always just one leg too) when in actual fact It’s my whole body causing me issues but that’s besides the point.

Disabled people have to deal with this line of questioning everyday simply for using aids & it needs to stop. And comments on my last 'Exactly' video calling me 'bitter', 'hateful' & a 'b*tch' for not wanting to answer strangers questions just because I use a mobility aid shows just how normalised it is for people to expect disabled people to answer invasive questions when they're just trying to go about their day.

Glasses are an aid too, but because they are more common they've just been normalised so I've never had to explain my astigmatism to a complete stranger whereas I've constantly felt forced to explain my traumatic & personal medical history behind my need for walking aids and that's not okay.

People also need to remember there is nothing wrong with using walking aids, just like there's nothing wrong with wearing glasses! Disability is a natural & beautiful part of human diversity which deserves to be respected.

Asking these kinds of questions is something I’ve definitely been guilty of in the past, they’ve somehow been ingrained into society, but let’s try & change that narrative so if you wouldn’t ask the same question to someone simply because they were wearing glasses don’t ask it to someone simply because they are using a #MobilityAid. If people want or need you to know about their disability/health condition they will tell you, always let them start that conversation. 

What questions would you like people to stop asking about your mobility aids and/or disabilities? Let me know in the comments.

Please share to your story for #DisabilityAwareness

‘When you finally feel safe, you will feel exhausted…After so long of being in survival mode your body recognises that you can now lay down your armour.’ - @lunahealings_777

I have been neglecting my mental health issues since I was 13 years old & have spent the last 10 years in survival mode fighting my body both physically & mentally. I have been pushing myself way too hard for far too long & something had to give. Finally feeling so safe & loved in my own home with my wonderful partner & pets meant my defences came down & the overwhelm & exhaustion of the last 10 years finally caught up with me causing a crisis. My anxiety, depression & my other mental health struggles became the enormous fire which I finally needed to start to fight, whilst still trying to manage the impact of these on my physical symptoms too.

It’s been a really tough time, I’ve lost my independence & confidence, & I feel a bit of a shell of myself at the moment but I am safe & I have spent the last month or so getting support in place, starting therapy & medications to help improve things. I really hope that I am starting to turn a corner but things are still up & down so I don’t know how active I will be on here. My mental health is something I find really difficult to talk about, which might seem strange since I am so open about my physical health, but I need to unlearn the shame I feel around mental illness like I have done with my physical chronic illnesses & I hope in the future I will be able to share more around my mental health journey too. 

Despite the urge, I am not going to apologise for taking the time out, which I have desperately needed, but I will apologise for any concern I’ve caused with my absence & thank everyone who checked in on me even when I’ve not been able to reply. And I cannot thank you all enough for your continued love, support & kindness. I hope to be back to making helpful content soon, but I have to get the help I need to get my sparkle back first.

 Sending Spoons & Love your way, CJ 🥄💜

This #Heatwave snuck up on me! As someone with a chronic illness majorly affected by heat I really struggle so I've put together my Top Ten cooling hacks to help you through the heatwave.

1. Hydrate, hydrate, hydrate - so simple but so important especially if you have certain conditions or take certain medications. If you need to top up your electrolytes my favourite for #POTS are @vitassium grape fastchews!

2. Ice Lollies - if you're struggling to keep up your water intake lollies are a great way to stay hydrated - you could even make your own!

3.Eating Smaller Meals more regularly means your body doesn't have to work so hard digesting food which can help in the heat.

4. Unless you can create a through breeze keep windows and curtains shut to keep the sun & the heat out! If you can find & stay in the room in your house opposite to direct sunlight.

5. @releafpack is my favourite ice pack because they're big, come in funky patterns & because they're made from beans & cotton it doesn't melt or sweat but keeps you cool. (gifted) 

6. My Ice Roller is amazing for targeted relief to the face & neck & is also great for your skin - you can find it in my chronic illness gadgets link.

7. The @koldtec headache halo is an escape pod for your head with specially engineered ice which doesn't get wet it can keep you cool for hours & the bamboo headband is comfy enough for any position plus its hands free!

8. Half fill a hot water bottle with cold water & pop it in the freezer for an hour or two and it's an easy ice pack. 

9. I love my wearable fans they're rechargeable, lightweight & easy to use & can also be easily placed on a surface. Ive had mine for a few years & you can find them in my chronic illness gadgets.

10. I use my @embrlabs embr wave 2 wristband for subtle cooling on the go you can try a cold compress or ice pack on the inside of your wrist to see if it will be helpful for you. Best thing is you can have it on at work & whilst you sleep! (gifted) 

Follow me for more helpful hacks & let me know in the comments your top tips for keeping cool!

Hello my loves, it's been a while 💕
I'm not going to lie I am still really struggling both mentally & physically. This year has been tough.

After initially getting a little support with my mental health I was told I would need a higher level of support than they could give me & referred on to several different services but it has now been months without help, tackling confusing systems & long waiting lists and I'm not sure where help is coming from or when despite the fact we've exhausted multiple options. And right now I am not in a place to chase or fight against the system.

Meanwhile I feel an intense pressure to get 'back to normal' & get back to work despite the fact nothing has changed. The feelings of knowing there's something you've been ignoring for years that's become disabling but you don't really have a name for it & you have no idea how to manage it throws me right back to the darkness I felt during my journey to diagnosis with my physical conditions. Only this time I have many of my physical symptoms flaring on top.

Chronic illness be it physically, mental or both has such a huge impact on every aspect of life; finances, relationships, often simply the ability to leave the house, and that's something I wish more people realised.

I'm sending so much love to anyone who resonates with this. I really appreciate you all & thank you for your love & support. I miss you dearly & hope I can get back soon but right now I have to focus on my health ✨

Happy Disability Pride Month!

This is the disability pride flag! After the original flag was found to have some accessibility issues the original creator Ann Magill collaborated with the disabled community on Tumblr to create a new flag in 2022.

The original version featured zig zag lines which represented having to adapt our lives to disability but on back-lit screens, especially when scrolling, this design created a strobe effect & caused problems for people with conditions such as epilepsy & migraine. The bright colours have also been desaturated. The warm colours (red & yellow) and the cool colours (blue & green) have been to be more accessible for those with sensory disabilities.

There are interesting meanings behind the different aspects of the disability pride flag:

The black field represents those who have lost their lives due to their not only due to their disabilities but also through ableism and its effects.

The parallel stripes represent solidarity within the disabled community despite our differences.

The 5 colours represent a different type of disability:
💚 Green is Sensory Perception Disabilities
💙 Blue is Mental Illness
🤍 White is Invisible Disabilities & Illnesses
💛 Yellow is Cognitive & Intellectual Disabilities
❤️ and Red is Physical Disabilities

What is Disability Pride Month?!

Disability Pride Month was born out of the disability rights movement and started in July 1990 to commemorate the passing of the Americans with disabilities act (ADA). It has since become a global celebration, as well as an act of protest in order to campaign for the world to be more inclusive of disabled people. The first Disability Pride Parade in the UK was held in Brighton in 2016.

The 3 main goals of Disability Pride Month are: 

✨ To change the way people think about and define disability.
✨ To break down and end the internalised shame felt by people with disabilities.
✨ To promote the belief in society that disability is a natural and beautiful part of human diversity in which people living with disabilities can take pride.

All of these things are so incredibly important and change needs to be made in wider society in regards to ableism, accessibility and representation. Especially as being disabled is one of the only minority and marginalised groups literally anyone can find themselves in overnight. Things are improving but I long for more disability representation in the media & in governance.

It's taken me a long time to discover my self worth as a person with a disability. And, don't get me wrong, being disabled is really tough especially with the awful systems which means getting basic needs met always seems to be a battle. But my disability has made me stronger, more resilient , more adaptable and has helped me find myself and the things that are important to me in a way I wouldn't have experienced otherwise. It's also helped me find the most incredible friends & community across the world. I am more than my disability but it's a huge part of me and I really wouldn't be me without it. 

I am disabled and I am proud.

Are you proud of your disability? How did you learn/how are you learning to be proud of your disability?

The real problem is, people think that life is a ladder, when it’s really a wheel. ✨

People think that if you aren’t climbing, you are falling backwards, you are failing. In reality we are always moving, sometimes we are at the top, sometimes we are at the bottom, sometimes we are in the middle. Sometimes we can help others, sometimes we are the ones who are in need of help and other times we are just muddling through. 

Before I got sick, society taught me that life was a ladder, that I had to be pushing for the next thing and the next, never stopping until I reached the top. Sometimes I would think I could see the top but it just turned out the ladder got higher and higher with each step I took, each thing I achieved, so when I got sick I fell hard! After becoming chronically ill I tried to start climbing back up the ladder like I had before, but it wasn’t working for me, I wasn’t always strong enough to pull myself up and I would get so frustrated with myself. I’d compare myself to those who I perceived as higher up the ladder and I’d feel stuck on the lower rungs.

But now I am trying to think of life as more of a wheel, I still have to push a little to keep ticking over but it’s not as hard. I’ve learnt that I have very little control over most of life’s ups and downs. I don’t have to be so hard on myself when the bumps in the road do come along and I try to remember that the good things will eventually come back around, even if it’s just for short periods. We don’t have to feel as stuck because we always keep going through this life. 

So let’s stop putting so much pressure on ourselves to climb and instead just keep rolling. 

What does it help you to think about when you’re feeling under pressure? Let us know in the comments, it might help someone else too!

The eyebrow hack I wish I'd had years ago when little 16 year old Jenni was struggling with what she now knows as Trichotillomania.

Deep breath. This is something I've never shared before. I held so much shame around it & always wanted to hide it. I actually filmed this video back in April & have been building up the confidence to talk about it so it can help even just one other person struggling.

Only a handful of people in my personal life know I struggle with pulling my eyebrows out, I don't feel it & often don't realise it's happening until I'm left with no brows at all & I've actually had no eyebrows for the vast majority of this year. I've laughed so hard when I've had eyebrow compliments. Thankfully I've managed to grow my brows out to full thickness again now but knowing I have this trick up my sleeve for future flares will make a world of difference.

It's down to these little temporary tattoo beauties that it's gone under the radar. They are so quick, easy & cheap, although I've had a few mishaps with very dodgy placement which luckily can be wiped away. You can use them over makeup (I usually do my base first) or use them make-up free.

Do you live with Dysautonomia? Then you need @vitassium (ad) in your life!

If you’ve been a follower for a long time you’ll know I love using Vitassium products to increase my electrolytes and help with my POTS symptoms. They are so good because they are formulated specifically for the chronic illness community & have lots of different options to suit your needs. Boosting electrolytes is a great way of helping to ease common symptoms of dysautonomia such as dizziness & fatigue by increasing blood volume.

Today I’m excited to share that Vitassium DrinkMix has finally launched in the UK in the Fruit Punch flavour! I was lucky enough to try it last year in the testing phases & knew it would become a regular addition to my day, especially like right now with this unexpected heatwave, I definitely wouldn't have got through this weekend without it! One serving of DrinkMix provides 500mg of Sodium & 100mg of Potassium but tastes just like a fruity squash. It makes hydration much more exciting than plain water too. 

If DrinkMix isn’t for you Vitassium also offer FastChews which are great for on the go, Grape flavour is my favourite! And for those who want to avoid flavours or sweetener their buffered electrolyte capsules are great to make sure you’re getting your sodium intake. All of their products are gluten free and vegan too.

You can join Vitassium Club to get lots of special offers and discounts. In the UK it means 20% off & free shipping on orders over £100! I definitely recommend checking out what Vitassium Club offers in your location and see what flavours they have available too!

September is Pain Awareness month & here are the top 5 things we wish you knew about living with Chronic Pain as suggested by my fabulous followers! Please share to your stories to raise awareness! 

1. We are always in pain! Yes even when we are smiling, laughing, chatting and working the pain is still there.

2. Our pain means we can't do a lot of the things we might once have been able to do. Even if you see us doing things we enjoy we often have to pay for it later & can spend days struggling as a result which you might not see.

3.Pain is unpredictable! We are just as upset as you, probably more so, when we have to cancel plans due to our pain but there is no way of predicting how bad it will be one day to the next, even one hour to the next.

4. Even with careful management & medications very few people manage to medicate to zero pain. A paracetamol doesn't take the pain away like it might do for you. Our daily pain levels would send most people to A&E if they were experiencing the same level of pain. We also cannot say we are in pain 24/7 it would be boring for everyone - but if we are saying something about it our pain level is very high!

5. Pain is exhausting and has a huge effect, not only physically (the pain itself, tight muscles, raised heart rates) but also mentally - its something you never truly get used to.

Is there anything you'd add to this list, let me know in the comments! Please share this to your stories and help make more people realise what it's really like to live with #ChronicPain

"That's the thing about pain, it demands to be felt" 💜

September is Pain awareness month.
Pain is something we all experience, one of the body’s natural mechanisms to protect us from harm - so why do we need a month dedicated to it? Because for those of us who live in pain constantly need to make others aware of how much it can impact a person's life.

Pain impacts our bodies whether it's soreness from tight muscles, sharp pain which takes our breath away or our bodies fighting the pain leaving us exhausted but unable to sleep. But pain also deeply affects our minds; the fear of pain or injury, not being able to complete simple tasks or commit to plans because of pain, the guilt & sadness of missing out because of the pain. Very few people who do not live with Chronic pain understand this.

A doctor once told me a procedure he wanted to do would be painful. 'Don't worry, I'm used to pain' I replied - I'd definitely been through worse. 'No one ever gets used to pain' he said profoundly. And he was right. I can't remember a time that I wasn't in pain & although I have learnt to better manage it over the 8+ years, pain has been my constant companion - and there really is no getting used to that. The last photo demonstrates that just because we are laughing or smiling, it doesn't mean we aren't in pain!

I often get asked to describe my pain but it’s hard because I experience so many different types of pain, in different areas of my body, which can be different from one hour to the next. Pain is also such a personal experience & no one else will ever truly know what the pain you experience feels like. But I want to raise awareness for the types of pain we feel so in the comments please share up to 5 words to describe your pain today. Sending so much love to everyone else living in pain.

Hello October & Hello Dysautonomia Awareness Month! 🩵💜

But what is Dysautonomia?! 🤷🏻‍♀️

Dysautonomia is an umbrella term used to describe the group of conditions that cause a malfunction in the Autonomic Nervous System (ANS). This is the system in the body which is in control of all the things the body does automatically, the things we don't think about. People with dysautonomia can have trouble regulating things like heart rate, blood pressure, digestion, temperature & more. This dysfunction can cause a whole range of symptoms from light-headedness, fainting, extreme blood pressure & heart rates, nausea, malnutrition & more.

Dysautonomia isn't rare & affects more than 70 million people worldwide. There's no cure for dysautonomia but it can be managed in many cases with medication & lifestyle changes & some people can experience a natural lessening in symptoms but it depends on the cause. Despite dysautonomia being fairly common it still takes most patients years to get diagnosed due to lack of awareness, especially in the medical profession, which is why awareness month is so important.

It can often be secondary to other conditions including diabetes, parkinsons, lupus, MS, RA & EDS.

The main types of dysautonomia are:

Neurocardiogenic Syncope (NCS), the most common type, caused by a drop on blood pressure & heart rate with various triggers.

POTS, the condition I live with, which causes high heart rates when upright, which affects around 1 in 100 teens. There's loads more on this on my YouTube channel & I'll be sharing more on here this month.

Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) a rare & fatal form affecting 350k patients worldwide. Affecting the over 40s it causes widespread autonomic nerve damage.

I'd love you to describe what Dysautonomia means to you or share what you wish people knew about Dysautonomia in the comments!

It’s #WorldMentalHealthDay & there are thousands of posts preaching ‘be kind’, talk, & get help, but what happens when you’ve admitted you need professional help, found the strength to ask for it but then help doesn’t come? Awareness is great, but action is what’s needed. More funding, more education, more fight. Today I’m choosing to be vulnerable & share my story, but I’m not alone. It’s difficult to fight & advocate for yourself when you’re unwell. So today I ask you not just to check in on a friend who’s struggling but advocate for them, ask if you can chase an appointment, find support services or just BE with them so they don’t feel so alone.

You’d never suspect a seemingly confident, bubbly person like me to be mentally ill. The shame, stigma & fear keeps it hidden behind closed doors. It gets worse when you try to open up only to find a distinct lack of understanding from services who have no idea how to begin helping someone with both physical & mental illnesses which are complex &, whilst separate, are totally intertwined. 

I’ve struggled with my mental health for 15 years. Last October I admitted I needed help & went to my local mental health services. I wasn’t seen until February, by which time I was deep into a crisis, unable to function. I had 4 sessions with a counselor before being told I was too complex & severe & referred on. I was thrown on medication without thought for my other conditions, causing horrible side effects, & then abandoned. I’ve since had multiple assessments with different services, having to relive my trauma over & over, & I’m still waiting for help. 

I got so desperate I booked a private psychiatry appointment & was officially diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Depression, Trichotillomania & Agoraphobia along with other potentials. I got a management plan but it relies on therapy & assessments which means more long waits & struggles to afford private therapy. I’m still very much not okay. But I’m lucky, what about those who don’t have that support or financial backup? It shouldn’t be this hard to access the care we need. 

What do you wish people knew about living with mental illness? Let me know in the comments

My Top 5 Hacks for Managing POTS 

This #DysautonomiaAwarenessMonth I wanted to share the top 5 hacks I use most regularly to help manage my #POTS & Orthostatic Hypotension Symptoms. Let me know what you’d add to the list in the comments so they’re filled with ideas to help fellow POTSies. 

First, I want to say that medication is the biggest help for me in managing symptoms on a daily basis. I’ve been on the same meds for years now & they were a game changer. I know they don’t work for everyone but there are lots of different options out there which can help.

1.Shower Stool! - This was one of the first things I got to help manage my POTS. It was the best gift I got on my 21st birthday,the gift of being able to shower much more easily. So many people put off this simple step for far too long & if that sounds like you, stop fighting it, your life will be SO much easier! I also shower in lukewarm water, have a window open & water nearby and can lean on my grab bar if my head needs extra support.

2. Saddle Stool on Wheels in my Kitchen - I have multiple places to sit in every room in my home but to be able to use the kitchen I needed a solution where I could move around & this has been the perfect hack for me.

3.Salt & Electrolytes - If you have low blood pressure or are easily dehydrated keeping your electrolytes up is so important but it can be difficult to get the recommended amount of sodium through food alone so I love @vitassium s range of products to give me the added boost. (Make sure you speak to a doctor before increasing your sodium)

4.Recumbent Exercise - This is something I’m trying to do more of & for me recumbent cycling with my pedals whilst lying on the sofa or floor watching Grey’s Anatomy is the perfect way. Swimming or adapted seated classes for things such as pilates are also a great option.

5. Cooling Gadgets - Heat is a major trigger for my POTS symptoms so to manage this heat intolerance I have a barrage of different cooling hacks in my arsenal from ice rollers to ice packs & headbands to wearable fans 

You can find out more about all my favourite chronic illness hacks & gadgets by visiting the Chronic Illness Hacks page on my website

Looking better = feeling better, right? Not necessarily! It's the 10th annual #InvisibleDisabilitiesWeek & the key focuses of the week are 'Listen, Believe, Support' so I want to ask the question; why do we believe & support the girl on the left when she says she's tired, in pain & has a disability but so often we wouldn't even listen to the girl on the right if she said the same? It's because our society is so focused on people 'looking well' when there really is no such thing.

People can't comprehend how we can smile & still be in pain but unfortunately a bit of red lippie won't cure my connective tissue disorder, it doesn't disappear because I look nice. It's this perception of invisible disability which is why it can take so long to get a correct diagnosis as patients are so often disbelieved, misunderstood and gaslit by loved ones and medical professionals alike. 

I wish people realised simple tasks which others take for granted like getting dressed up or putting on make up can be extremely exhausting for disabled people & often leave us feeling much worse than we did before. It can also cause us pain. Mobility aids also give completely different kinds of support so different aids don't mean we are feeling better or worse they simply mean different support is needed. And using no aids at all often means we will actually be feeling worse rather than better as we are without the support which helps us, so have a think before you say 'it's good to see you without your stick, you must be feeling better' - it's simply not true. We might be able to go without in the moment but there will be repercussions that you will not see. 

So before you question someone on social media, roll your eyes at someone using a disabled loo or leave a nasty note on someone's car who is parked in a disabled bay please remember there is no such thing as 'looking disabled' and many people are fighting battles within their own bodies which you know nothing about so be kind, always! And feel free to tell someone they look great but please never ever tell them they look well!

What is POTS?

October is #DysautonomiaAwarenessMonth so I wanted to talk about the form of #Dysautonomia that I live with which is called POTS.

We can break POTS down into its 4 terms:

Postural: a change in the posture of the body i.e from lying to sitting or sitting to standing

Orthostatic: caused by an upright posture (sitting up or standing)

Tachycardia: an abnormally high heart rate usually over 100bpm

Syndrome: a collection of symptoms

Overall POTS can be diagnosed when a person's heart rate consistently rises by 30bpm (40bpm for the under 20s) on changing to an upright position & causes symptoms such a light-headedness, fatigue, nausea, etc.

These symptoms occur because usually when you sit up or stand gravity pulls blood downwards. Your body quickly counteracts this by narrowing the blood vessels & increasing your heart rate slightly. This system doesn't work properly in POTS patients causing a drop in blood supply to the heart & brain causing the heart to race in order to compensate which can cause disabling symptoms.

There are many causes for POTS including it being a secondary condition to thing like EDS, CFS or autoimmune conditions. It can also present after a virus or bacterial infection so there has been a rise in case recently caused by c*vid. It has also been suggested it can be triggered by trauma or pregnancy. POTS can be managed using medication & lifestyle changes. Remission can occur but depends on the cause of your POTS, if it's secondary to a long term condition its probably not going away. 

POTS is often misdiagnosed as anxiety and it takes people an average of 7 years to get a diagnosis. So please share to your stories to help raise awareness & follow me for more info & helpful management tips.

We all know the phrase 'Don't judge a book by its cover' so why are we so quick to judge those with hidden disabilities? #InvisibleDisabilitiesWeek

When people tell me: 'you look well', I think honesty is the best policy & reply 'I wish I felt it' and wait for the awkward silence that ensues.

Why can't people just say 'you look nice'? What does how I look have to do with how well I am? Am I not allowed to look nice AND have a disability? Am I supposed to look unwell all the time, that's pretty depressing? What does disability look like anyway?! The list goes on.

People sometimes say 'oh I would never have known you were disabled' like it's a compliment, but it's not. It just goes to show how deep the mask of internalised ableism goes because I'm the only one who suffers when I've had to hide my disability to make the lives of others easier or make them feel better, because the pain doesn't go away. And I am someone who is very open about their disability, there are so many people who do not wish to be but it doesn't mean they aren't struggling.

Pain is invisible. Fatigue is invisible. Headaches are invisible. Tachycardia is invisible. Mental illness is invisible. Very few of the symptoms I live with daily can be seen & by the time they are visible to you, they are extreme! Sometimes we can smile through the pain & push through the fatigue. But remember just because you can't see a disability or chronic health condition it doesn't make it any less real.

This photo is not from different days or even hours. It was taken the same second, after getting back from work one day. I ripped off my eyebrow tattoo & fake eyelash & took off half my makeup to show that despite being so full of joy for an hour or so I'm still the physically & mentally ill girl underneath just trying her best.

So remember, 'everyone is fighting a battle you know nothing about; be kind, always'

What bits of invisible illness do you wish people could see? Sometimes I wish others could live in my body just for 1 minute to appreciate what it feels like 🙊

To Brighter Days ✨

This year's been a dark one, for the world, for disabled people & for me personally. As many of you know I've struggled massively with my mental & physical health this year. I'm still in the depths of my anxiety, depression & physical pain but singing has been a bright spark & saving grace amongst the darkness.

I joined my local @thesingspace choir ( @chelmsfordmusicaltheatrechoir ) earlier this year at a time when I was terrified to leave the house alone, Ian had to take me to my first session because I was too scared but it quickly turned into the highlight of my week. I've met the most incredible group of people & been given opportunities I could never have imagined, like singing solo with malonegareth & his amazing team not once but twice on tour.

Brighter Days isn't a song I would have picked for myself to sing (my range is not what it used to be!) But it's the song that came to me when I needed it most, I think it might help you too. In some spark of bravery I'd put myself forward for 1 tiny line in a medley to sing solo but my incredible choir leader @sarahmahonyvocalcoach told me to give Brighter Days a try when we were preparing for the concerts, I nervously agreed & before I knew it I was singing it on a stage in Ipswich in front of 1000 people. 

I've always loved performing but It's extremely rare to see visibly disabled people performing on big stages so I thought my life in the theatre was over but that needs to change so others can see that it's possible & I've seen just how accessible it can be when you have the right support.

I know I'm not the best singer but it's the first thing I ever put out online as a child because I loved it. Unfortunately I was trolled horribly for it at the time & despite my singing improving over the years my confidence disappeared but I'm going to take this moment for little Jenni & be proud of myself. I also want to share my immense gratitude for Sing Space, Sarah, my amazing choir friends & Gareth for your trust & support, you'll never know what it's meant to me.

So here's to #BrighterDays! What song or activity brings you joy on dark days? Let me know in the comments!

#DisabledSinger

The holidays are a busy time of year for social gatherings so I asked my followers what they wish non-disabled people knew about socialising with a disability or chronic illness & this is what they wanted you to know ahead of the festive season. 

1.The admin is intense - there is a lot of planning that goes into simply leaving the house as a disabled person: is there an accessible way to travel, will i have to book assistance or organize a carer, is the venue accessible to get into,is there somewhere I can rest if i need to - the list goes on & on - help your disabled pals out by finding out some of this info for us & booking accessible venues.

2.Many of our conditions can fluctuate by the hour so it’s really hard for us to make future plans. Remember we are just as upset, if not more upset, than you are if we have to cancel last minute or leave early but it really isn’t our fault. We want so badly to spend time with you but sometimes our health has other plans. We might not always be able to make it but please don’t stop inviting us to things.

3.Socialising is much more exhausting than you think for us. Please respect our energy & the effort we’ve made to be there because between the planning & the event itself there will be consequences for us which could mean we spend days in bed. Please don’t push us to participate in extra activities, just watching & being present can be enjoyable & is often exhausting enough.

4.Please remember that just because we look good does not necessarily mean we feel good, we often have to fake being well in order to have a good time. Pain & so many other symptoms are invisible & often we are pushing our limits to spend time with you. Don’t make assumptions based on how we look.

5.Finally winter is a nasty time for viruses so please try & avoid attending events if you are unwell or at the very least let other people attending know you are sick so they can make an informed decision because for many vulnerable people it’s just not worth the risk.

What would you add to this list? Let me know in the comments and share this to educate your loved ones.

Top Tips on Managing the Holidays with a #ChronicIllness 

With social & financial pressures, the holiday season can be stressful for many but when you have a chronic illness those pressures can be intensified. So much expectation is placed on us 'because it's Christmas' & we’re often forced to do more than we usually would, meaning it can be the most flare inducing time of the year. Chronic illness doesn't know or care that it’s Christmas, pain & fatigue don't just disappear because it's the holidays. So here are my festive Health hacks to avoid flares & burnout.

🎄 Set clear boundaries & say no: Don't push yourself just because it's Christmas because the only person who will suffer is you. We can often get stuck between family & visit multiple destinations to keep the peace but if you wouldn’t do it all in one day any other time of the year don't do it for the holidays. If you really need to see everyone try & push for a more accessible option, like a zoom call.

✨ Create a rest space to get away from it all. Whether you're at home or visiting family, try& prearrange a space you can go & rest if things get too much, whether it’s a separate room with a bed or a comfy pillow in your car. If you talk about this in advance it's easier to excuse yourself on the day too.

🎅🏼 Simplify & Prioritise where you can! We can't do it all, especially at Christmas. We might want perfectly wrapped gifts & homemade food but in reality gift bags & pre prepared food are much easier meaning you can save more time & energy on the things you really love. This year I took Christmas cards off my to do list as they were just an extra thing I really didn't need to spend spoons on.

🎄 Ask for help. Again if there’s particular holiday tasks you struggle with, don't suffer in silence, ask someone else if they can help you or take on that task themselves. If you don't have the physical support, reaching out to a friend virtually for emotional support might be just as helpful.

Let me know in the comments how you are spending the holidays & what your top tip is for making it easier to manage?

ad Come on tour with me and my choir in my brand new @motabilityscheme car!

I definitely can’t lift my wheelchair in and out of the car, and Ian was constantly hurting his back lifting it in and out of our old car. It meant that I had to rely on him whenever I wanted to go for a drive, so it was really important to both of us to join the Motability Scheme. Getting our new car and hoist under the scheme has given me so much more freedom and independence, and opened up incredible opportunities I would never have been able to take part in otherwise.

Joining my choir has brought so much joy and allowed me to find a little of myself again - which I’ve been missing this year whilst my mental health has been so low.

Lots of disabled people are eligible for the Motability Scheme but don’t realise it, so head to the link in my stories to check if you’re eligible!

This is my first Motability Scheme car, and it’s still all very new to me so if you have been thinking of joining the scheme please feel free to ask any questions in the comments or in my dms and I’ll do my best to answer them.

Goodbye 2023 ✨

And good riddance! I've had such an up and down year so I wanted to make sure I shared both the Instagram highlights and the harsh reality of chronic physical & mental illness.

Looking back I really have achieved a lot this year: my first runway at London Fashion Week, Travelling to Belgium as a finalist of a European award, Expanding my modelling portfolio & doing my first in-person professional public speaking job. But all of these are tinged with the memories of the panic, anxiety & pain I felt during all of them. 

I also achieved a lot personally applying for support schemes and getting the help in place that I have desperately needed for years which has been as difficult, long & stressful a process as I thought it would be but has been so worth it. I also braved a lot of new medical investigations & commited to medication & therapy for my mental health. I'm still having a really tough time physically & mentally and I'm still waiting on the right support but I have so much more in place to help and I hope this continues in the new year & I hope I can share more with you so you can find more support too.

I have felt so isolated, misunderstood & afraid this year, the news has been constantly heavy for the world & for disabled people especially and I've spent a huge amount of time in deep depression but there have been beautiful glimmers of joy too, spending time with my beautiful friends, family & pets. I got to celebrate at 2 weddings, join my choir with such a supportive & bright group of people, find new peaceful hobbies just for me and got a huge amount of independence & freedom back with my wheelchairs.

Sending love to everyone who has had a tough year. Remember that a new year isn't suddenly going to make things better, it's difficult to avoid the narrative that a new year changes everything, but it's important to be proud of all that we have survived. We made it through 2023, I hope against hope that in 2024 things will hopefully get a little better.

Sending so much love & a huge thank you for sticking with me this year - Here's to 2024.
